'''''Neoboletus luridiformis''''', known until 2014 as '''''Boletus luridiformis''''', is a fungus of the [[Boletaceae|bolete family]], all of which produce mushrooms with tubes and pores beneath their [[pileus (mycology)|caps]]. It is found in [[Northern Europe]] and [[North America]], and is [[common name|commonly known]] as the '''scarletina bolete''', for its red pores (yellow when young).

Edible when cooked properly. When raw it can cause gastric upset. Can be confused where the two species coincide with the poisonous ''[[Rubroboletus satanas]]'', which has a paler cap.

==Taxonomy==
''Boletus luridiformis'' was originally described by [[Christian Hendrik Persoon]] in 1796 as ''Boletus erythropus'' – a name since reduced to synonymy<ref name=Phillips06>{{cite book | author = Roger Phillips | year = 2006  | title = Mushrooms | publisher = Pan MacMillan | isbn = 978-0-330-44237-4}}</ref> – which derived its [[specific name (botany)|specific name]] from the [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] ''ερυθρος'' ("red") and ''πους'' ("foot"),<ref name=Liddell1980>{{cite book | author = Liddell, Henry George | author-link = Henry George Liddell | author2 = Robert Scott | author2-link = Robert Scott (philologist) | last-author-amp = yes | year = 1980 | title = A Greek-English Lexicon (Abridged Edition) | publisher = [[Oxford University Press]] | location = United Kingdom | isbn =978-0-19-910207-5| title-link = A Greek-English Lexicon }}</ref> referring to its red coloured stalk. Its [[French (language)|French]] name, [[:fr:Bolet à pied rouge|bolet à pied rouge]] or 'red-foot bolete' is a literal translation.

Genetic analysis published in 2013 showed that ''B. luridiformis'' and many (but not all) red-pored boletes were part of a ''dupainii'' clade (named for ''[[Boletus dupainii]]''), well-removed from the core group of ''[[Boletus edulis]]'' and relatives within the Boletineae. This indicated that it needed to be placed in a new genus.<ref name="Nuhn 2013">{{cite journal |vauthors=Nuhn ME, Binder M, Taylor AF, Halling RE, Hibbett DS |title=Phylogenetic overview of the Boletineae |journal=Fungal Biology |year=2013 |volume=117 |issue=7–8 |pages=479–511 |doi=10.1016/j.funbio.2013.04.008 |pmid=23931115}}</ref> It became the [[type species]] of the new genus ''[[Neoboletus]]'' in 2014.<ref name="Vizzini 2014"/>

==Description==
[[Image:Boletus_erythropus_2010_G1.jpg|left|thumb|''N. luridiformis'', found in Ukraine. After cutting, the yellow interior quickly turns blue due to oxidation.]]'''''Neoboletus luridiformis''''' is a large solid fungus with a bay-brown hemispherical to convex [[Pileus (mycology)|cap]] that can grow up to {{convert|20|cm|in|0|abbr=on}} wide, and is quite felty initially. It has small orange-red pores that become rusty with age, and bruise blue to black. The tubes are yellowish-green, and become blue quickly on cutting. The fat, colourful, densely red-dotted yellow [[Stipe (mycology)|stem]] is 4–12 cm (2–5 in) high, and has '''no network pattern''' (reticulation). The flesh stains dark blue when bruised; broken, or cut.<ref name=Phillips06/> There is little smell. The spore dust is olive greenish-brown.

The similar ''[[Suillellus luridus]]'' has a network pattern on the stem, and seems to prefer chalky soil. ''Rubroboletus satanas'' also has a stem network, but a very-pale whitish cap.
''[[Rubroboletus pulcherrimus]]'' has a reticulate stipe, and is larger in size.<ref name="Desjardin 2015">{{cite book |author=Desjarind D.E, Wood M.G, Stevens F.A. |title=California Mushrooms. The comprensive identification guide |year=2015 |publisher=Timber Press |location=Portland, Oregon |page=354 |isbn=978-1-60469-353-9}}</ref>

==Distribution and habitat==
The fungus grows in [[deciduous]] or [[coniferous]] woodland, in summer and autumn, in Europe. It is often found in the same places as ''[[Boletus edulis]]''. It is also widely distributed in [[North America]], and is especially common under [[spruce]] in its range from Northern [[California]] to [[Alaska]]. In Eastern North America it grows with both soft, and hardwood trees.<ref name=Arora2nd>{{cite book |author=David Arora |year=1986 |title=Mushrooms Demystified |publisher=Ten Speed Press |isbn=978-0-89815-169-5 |url=https://archive.org/details/mushroomsdemysti00aror_0 }}</ref> It seems to prefer acid soils.

==Toxicity and edibility==
Mild tasting, ''Neoboletus luridiformis'' is edible after longer cooking (some literature recommends 20 minutes). It is commonly collected in several European countries. 

When raw or insufficiently cooked it can cause gastric upset, for the same reason it is not recommended for drying. Caution is advised as it resembles other less edible blue-staining boletes, and should thus be avoided by novice mushroom hunters.<ref name="Arora2nd"/>{{page needed|date=January 2018}}
